Award.AwardTitle: Collaboration for Excellence in Science and Math Education (CESAME)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB), Lawson State Community College and Birmingham City Schools are partnering to greatly enhance the entry of science and math majors into careers in secondary education in high needs schools, introducing STEM majors to education opportunities during the formative stage of their college programs and providing support through a program of academic and practical experiences.

Two models being tested are: 1) a multi-year program, engaging freshmen and providing scholarships for junior, senior and 5th year students and 2) a one-year program for students with a STEM undergraduate degree. Each program is enrolling 20 students as scholarship recipients, and leads to a Master degree. Students enter the program during their freshman year as facilitators in UAB?s Summer Science Institute for secondary students. There are 25 potential scholarship candidates facilitating these summer programs, from which the 40 scholarship recipients are chosen. During their initial 3 years of teaching, each Noyce graduate is assigned a Center for Community OutReach Development (CORD) STEM specialist to insure that they receive appropriate support by UAB faculty and mentor teachers. A Learning Resource Lab provides a place for teachers to come for guidance and support on an as-needed basis.

The Intellectual Merit of Collaboration for Excellence in Science and Math Education (CESAME) includes the testing of the design, resources and performance of an innovative method to recruit promising STEM students to be transformative secondary STEM education leaders. The Broader Impacts are in the 40 excellent STEM teachers who plan to be teachers in underserved schools and a sustained platform to supply highly qualified STEM teachers.

Performance_Institution.Name: UAB Center for Community OutReach Development

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
CESAME has focused on creating a new cadre of highly trained K-12 Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) teachers, especially focused on recruiting underrepresented minority (URM) students to STEM education careers. CESAME brings together outstanding undergraduate and graduate students with university STEM and Education faculty and master teachers to develop the students into excellent STEM K-12 educators. In the past 5 years, CESAME has trained/is training 14 undergraduates and 31 graduate students (MAEd) to enter the secondary STEM education workforce. All but 5 of the 45 students persevere in STEM teacher education and secondary STEM teaching careers. 28% of CESAME students are minority, 45% come from families living below the national poverty line and 25% are teaching (have taught) in rural Alabama schools. CESAME II is committed to increasing recruitment of these groups, with 35% teaching in rural schools. These newly developed teachers are much needed teaching resources for the state and the nation.

In addition to fulfilling its primary mission (as above), CESAME has changed education in Alabama in several important ways, and thus laid a foundation for education in Alabama and other states. First, it has developed state-of-the-art secondary STEM teachers, who are more competent than ever in understanding STEM concepts and adept at STEM skills. Most of these students will not enter the STEM careers that we typically think of, but they will be in STEM-related careers which will dominate the 21st century. Second, CESAME has changed the state’s teacher preparation and made it much more flexible, so that STEM professionals are enticed to use their skills in educating the next generation. These teachers are trained in inquiry-based techniques, so that their students are interested and engaged in STEM learning. Third, CESAME has allowed us to move the Alabama Math, Science and Technology Initiative (AMSTI) training (the main in-service teacher training and resourcing program in the state) to preservice levels, thus allowing teachers to use the myriad of AMSTI resources on day 1 in their classroom experience. This has become not just an advantage for UAB and CESAME students, but it is now offered state wide in response to the successful roll out in the CESAME program. Thus CESAME has laid a great foundation for the continuation of this program in CESAME II at UAB.
